Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Taiwan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Josh Egan of The University of Minnesota Conservation Biology Program to conduct a research project in Biological sciences during the summer of 2013 at National Chiayi University in Chiayi, Taiwan. The project title is "The Evolution of Generalist Feeding Strategies in Marine Fishes." The host scientist is Dr. Chien-Hsien Kuo.

The evolution of specialized trophic niches has been extensively researched. This research has shown that trophic niche specialization is stimulated by complex, stable, and productive habitats and promotes speciation and the evolution of phenotypic diversity. In contrast, generalist trophic niches, although recognized as common, have been the focus of few evolutionary studies. This represents a significant gap in our understanding of the generation and distribution of biodiversity. To address this gap, this research uses phylogenetic comparative methods to test two fundamental hypotheses regarding the evolution of generalist trophic niches: (1) the evolution of generalist trophic niches is associated with transitions to habitats with temporally variable food webs and (2) the evolution of generalist trophic niches is associated with morphological and behavioral adaptation. The project uses the clupeiform fishes as a study system to address these questions because this order is diverse, widely distributed, and contains trophic generalists.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, this research will advance our understanding of evolutionary processes and species richness patterns, knowledge that is increasingly used to inform biodiversity conservation and management efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ecological niche is the set of resources an organism uses (e.g. food and habitat) and the conditions in which it can persist (e.g. tolerable range of temperatures). Research on the evolution of the niche is urgently needed because many theories in ecology and evolution rely on poorly tested assumptions regarding the effects of different niche characteristics. My doctoral research will improve our understanding of niche evolution by investigating how diet and habitat aspects of the ecological niche evolve and how diet and habitat niche size affects rates at which new species are generated. This research requires that I have a thorough understanding of the diets of the clupeiform fishes (herrings, anchovies, and relatives), the group I use to investigate my research questions. Unfortunately, diet is not well studied for many of the species in this group. To fill this gap I conducted research funded by National Science Foundation East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes Program (EAPSI) in Taiwan during the summer of 2013 to describe the diets and morphology of clupeiform fishes in Taiwan.

 

I collected clupeiform specimens with the help of undergraduate students from National Chiayi University (Chiayi, Taiwan). We completed 50 separate trips to acquire fish from the wild, fish markets, and directly from fishermen in Taiwan. We collected fish in estuarine and near shore habitats with both muddy and sandy substrates in Kenting (Pingtung County), Haomei (Tainan county), the Anping district of Tainan (Tainan County), and Houlong (Mioli County). Additionally, we collected fish from Donggang (Pingtung County), Budai (Chiayi County), Keelung City, Dasi (Taoyuan County), and Tainan (Tainan County) fish markets. Fish were acquired directly from fishermen in Anping Tainan. These collecting trips yielded 115 tissue samples and over 500 whole specimens from 15 species of clupeiforms (Encrasicholina heteroloba, Encrasicholina punctifer, Thryssa chefuensis, Thryssa dussumieri, Thryssa hamiltonii, Thryssa setirostris, Stolephorus insularis, Stolephorus waitei, Dussumieria acuta, Spratelloides gracilis, Sardinella gibbosa, Sardinella lemuru, Nematalosa come, Nematalosa japonica, Ilisha melastoma).

 

My 2013 EAPSI research produced a detailed description of the diets of 12 clupeiform species. Zooplankton appears to be an important prey item for nearly all species captured. However, 2 species were found to primarily consume shrimp and fish and 2 were found to primarily consume detritus. Additionally, I measured 10 morphological traits for all 15 species collected. Initial results show substantial variation in all measured traits and statistical modeling suggests that all traits have some power for predicting clupeiform diets. These morphological data have been combined with additional data collected from museum specimens to construct a robust statistical model for predicting clupeiform diets for which no data are available.

 

The diet and morphology information collected for my EAPSI research has improved our understanding of the biology several clupeiforms found in Taiwan. A comprehensive understanding of clupeiform biology is important because in many ecosystems, clupeiforms are a key pathway for energy transfer between lower and higher trophic levels. Finally, my EAPSI research in Taiwan represents a critical component of my doctoral research, which will advance the disciplines of evolutionary biology, fisheries, conservation biology, biogeography, and ecology by providing insight into the evolutionary relationships of clupeiforms, the factors driving niche evolution, and how niche size impacts the rates at which new species are generated.
